title: In california, if my husband dies with credit card debt in his name only am I responsible to pay the debt?
question: My husband died with credit card debts on credit cards in his name only, which I never signed on, never used, and never co-signed for either. All of our assets are in a trust, so there will be no probate. Am I responsible for that debt? We did have a credit card that was in both our names that I used and that I have no doubt about paying over time. However, I do not have funds to pay my husband's personal card debt. What should I do and how do I handle the credit card company (BofA) when they come to collect the debt.
answers:
You do not have personal liability for your deceased husband's credit cards that unless you signed the credit application. Your separate property is not liable for your deceased husband's debts. However, the community property is available to satisfy those obligations. If all assets in the trust is community property then it could all be available to satisfy your husband's creditors.

As you and your husband had a trust a probate of your husband's estate is not required. The trust assets therefore are not made public information (as would happen if there were a probate.) The significance is that your husband's creditors limited access to trust property information.

If you lack the resources to pay your husband's obligations you should consider negotiating settlements with each creditor that contacts you. Those that do not contact you are subject to the one year (from your husband's date of death) statute of limitations.

If the debt is a community debt (was of benefit to the community) then you are responsible for the debt as much as your husband was. Purchases made during your marriage would be difficult to prove were not community purchases. It makes no difference that the card was in his name only.

Furthermore, most likely your husband's estate is liable for the debt. The placement of your husband's assets into a revocable trust did not shield those assets from creditors. It is the responsibility of the trustee of that trust (most likely yourself?) to deal with your husband's creditors.

I suggest you consult with a probate/trust administration attorney in your county for a review of the individual creditors' accounts. Bring a list of assets as of your husband's date of death to the meeting, as well.

Best to you.

You are not personally responsible for your husband's debts. If a bank asked me to pay my deceased spouse's debt from my personal assets, I would likely just say "no." However, I expect you are the trustee of a trust that holds assets of both you and your husband, and that the trust has terms which instruct the trustee to pay the deceased spouse's debts. As trustee you should pay the debts, but not using more than his 1/2 of the trust assets (I am assuming you and your husband each owned 1/2 of the trust as community property).

If the trust assets are not in a form you can used to pay the debts, like a house, then you could use your own funds to pay the debts. If the bank is not paid, they would have to sue your husband's estate. The bank has only one year to file such a law suit. They would win such a law suit and get a Judgment. But they would lose the portion of any lawsuit against you personally, regardless of what was bought with the borrowed money. With a Judgment, they could then lien the house, and they might get paid latter.

If the trust has such assets, and if the bank calls, you could ask to settle the debt for a decreased amount. The bank may go for this settlement because they do not want to pay the cost to sue on the hopes that they will get their money back. You could say "I will personally pay 1/3 in cash now if you agree to cancel the remaining debt." Get it in writing if they agree.

Good luck.

I'm sorry about your husband's death. The answer to whether you are liable for your husband's credit card debt depends, in part, on what the credit cards were used to purchase - if they were used to purchase items that benefitted the "community", then you can be held responsible for them. Even though his assets won't go through probate, they are subject to claims of his creditors for up to one year. There is a procedure to shorten that time period. I suggest you contact a local estate planning lawyer to find out how to use the procedure and whether it would benefit you in your particular situation.
